newsitem.title: USA: Kevorkian attorney says woman took her own life.
newsitem.headline: Kevorkian attorney says woman took her own life.

text.p: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's lawyer said Friday a 59-year-old Virginia woman took her own life Thursday but he refused to say whether the assisted suicide crusader was involved.
Helen Livengood, who suffered from chronic arthritis and weighed about 50 pounds, died by "her own hand", attorney Geoffrey Fieger said at a news conference.
"They would probably rule it on the death certificate a suicide," he said. "However, her intent was to end suffering."

Police in Romulus, south of Detroit, said in a statement Friday morning that they began investigating the woman's death Thursday evening after receiving a call that her body had been found at a hotel near the Detroit Metropolitan Airport.
Livengood's body was turned over to the Wayne County Medical Examiner's Office for an autopsy. A spokesman for the office said the autopsy had not been completed yet.
WXYZ-TV reported a maid at the Hilton Suites hotel found Livengood's body and a note in her room that said to call her attorney, Fieger.
Fieger said he represented Livengood only for the purpose of making the announcement regarding her death. He would not say if Kevorkian was involved.
"I have no statement or comment with regard to Dr. Kevorkian," he said.
Livengood and her husband chartered a private jet to Detroit from Richmond, Virginia Thursday. Her husband returned home alone the same day.

Kevorkian was free on bond stemming from his latest scrape with Michigan authorities. A grand jury last November charged him and one of his longtime allies with violating Michigan's unwritten "common law" prohibiting assisted suicide by helping Loretta Peabody, 54, of Ionia, Michigan die Aug. 30.

Kevorkian agreed not to be present at any more assisted suicides as part of his bond condition terms. Last month the bodies of two women -- one in Kevorkian's Volkswagen van -- were left for authorities to find.
He never admitted involvement with their deaths, but Fieger later told a reporter, "You have to have been born under a rock yesterday not to know who was involved in these cases."
At the request of prosecutors, an Ionia County Circuit Court judge last month tightened Kevorkian's bond conditions, but only for the county in rural west-central Michigan.
Kevorkian has formally acknowledged being present at 45 assisted suicides since 1990.
